review_title: Company that is placing priority on profits over people. Is this okay in 2021?
pros: If you are friends with your hiring manager, they bust the comp range for people they know or worked with in past companies. Qualifications or lack thereof are not a problem.
cons:
Has cut employees' health insurance, 401k match, PTO in past two years. Previously, PTO could be carried over to following year, or cashed out by employees, and would be paid out to employees upon separation from the company. The company ended these practices via a surprise Friday night email in 2019. Also, annual PTO was reduced for employees with more than 8 years tenure. In 2020, the 401k match, which was only 3% to begin with, was eliminated. Health plan offerings were reduced to all physician group employees in 2021, and that's likely to be expanded to the rest of the organization in 2022.

Do your research and internet search news stories on this company. They are regularly in court defending (frequently unsuccessfully) significant CMS compliance violations, medical malpractice suits, wrongful employment termination lawsuits and more. Cutting corners and flaunting regulatory requirements are part of the culture here.
Advice to Management
Balance those multimillion dollar bonuses to the CEO with basic health and welfare benefits for your employees. Stop gutting health and welfare benefits to your workforce. Company is supposed to be in the business of caring for patients, so take care of the employees who are providing that care. Healthcare workers are not exactly overpaid. Many of the front line care givers are the lowest paid employees in the company, and the least able to absorb these cuts to basic employment benefits.
Helpfu

pros: Pay is good for the area. Offer sign on bonuses
cons:
Company doesn’t support the staff. Almost zero lift equipment, assistive technology. Do not adhere to national standards of safety and quality. Poor leadership. The staff are not empowered or encouraged to be involved in shared governance. Honestly, it was shocking after being in 5 other hospitals to come here and feel like I had gone back in time 25 years. This system clearly is either stealing money from their patients and the bedside staff or have no idea how to run a business.
Advice to Management
Create healthy work environments that will retain staff. It isn’t all about number of staff. Invest in equipment and technology that can assist staff in doing their jobs. Get rid of poor leaders and revamp some of the leadership in hospitals that are struggling (Hilton Head). Invest in your employees and nurture talent and grassroots ideas and changes. Implement the LEAN process to create more engaged and efficient processes that will improve the work environment and ultimately generate a positive bottom line. Covid is not an excuse to throw everything out the window and batter the staff to exhaustion when it isn’t necessary. I worked in a system that continued to invest in their employees and work environments actually nurturing them more not less. This has been a very disappointing and eye opening experience. I will never work for a profit hospital again if this is the normal way of operations.
Helpfu

pros: If you work at Orchestra Place you can park near the building. That’s literally it.
cons:

Chaos, Pay is insulting 

Be sure to ask questions about their systems and who will train you. I’ll spoil it for you. You’ll be using programs that haven’t been updated since 2003 and you will be expected to know what and how they want things even though they won’t tell you. 

The Access Center/Call Center is trash. 
My manager was flighty and confused about everything. 
I was given a laptop that semi worked and that overheated often. 

They really don’t know what they want you to do and will retaliate in their own way if you countered their offer. 
My manager made several alarming comments my first week, I knew immediately this wouldn’t be a good fit. She was the most bizarre person I’ve ever encountered in my career and I’m honored to not have to interact with her anymore.
Advice to Management
Need more competent people in leadership

pros: None, this place was one of the worst establishments that I have ever worked at.
cons:
Where to start...

Management managing upwards. Constant changing priorities, being run amok by ex-consultants and cronies of the CEO. If you want to look at a company that cares about employees, look no further than the rating for HCA where their CEO is at74% approval ratings vs a lowly 30%. I wonder why? Read the reviews. They care about their employees and are committed to them. Take Tenet first getting government funds, then furloughing employees only to axe them later to prop up earnings? Who does that and cares about a community built by the employees that actually do the real work? Don't get fooled by a marketing slogan, this company is all about profits and upper management getting ready to (golden) parachute once their contracts are up.
Advice to Management
Get rid of the management team that protects one another and get some real leadership in to overhaul the company focused on patients and not profits.

advice_to_mgmt: Get rid of the management team that protects one another and get some real leadership in to overhaul the company focused on patients and not profits.

pros: Nice people. They do offer per diems a 401k plan without having to wait a year. That is the only benefit per diems receive.
cons:
There are no pay raises for per diem operators. When it comes to reviews you can expect to get all 3's across the board. It doesn't matter how good you are or how often you agree to work extra. The no raises causes many to leave for jobs that will at least give them a cost of living raise. None of that at Tenet! They don't seem to give a fig about their per diems. Many people at the facility I work at say they are a notoriously cheap company.
Advice to Management
Get smart. Look at your policies for per diems and consider giving them yearly pay increases.

pros: GREAT benefits, helpful and caring co-workers, and great pay
cons:
I have worked for Baptist Health System for almost five years. I am proud to say I work here, yet not proud to be a Tenet employee. It seems as if every year the bottom line becomes more important than patient care. My manager has no experience working in a hospital system, and seems like even less experience in management, yet he talks a good game and SAYS all the right things. Actions speak louder than words. More and more good employees are being laid off to secure the bottom line. Which means that the ones who are lucky enough to make “the cut” are left with more responsibilities. There are so many changes, which change is inevitable, but these changes are made from month to month and it is hard for anyone to be successful. Corporate in Dallas makes decisions based off of “budget,” yet have no clue as to the value of the employees that they are laying off nor the value of their current employees.
Advice to Management
Visit your hospital systems and their ancillary facilities more often to actually see the good that is being done, rather than just focusing on numbers and budgets. It costs more to hire and train a new employee than to retain one. Maybe that will solve some of the budget issues.

advice_to_mgmt: Visit your hospital systems and their ancillary facilities more often to actually see the good that is being done, rather than just focusing on numbers and budgets. It costs more to hire and train a new employee than to retain one. Maybe that will solve some of the budget issues.

review_title: CEO Ronald Rittenmeyer - "Tenet will look at aggressively offshoring jobs
pros: Only good thing was the paycheck.
cons:
CEO started offshoring all inside jobs that had to do with accounting and purchasing due to Tenet being billions of dollars in debt. Any new software that came out we were to QA test it live with minimal (1 hr) training. Forced to train the overseas employees taking our jobs otherwise we would not get our severance package. Florida Service Center and Conifer laid off as jobs are going to the "GBC" in Manila. After four months of training, overseas employees are still making mistakes that we have to clean up. If you are looking into joining Tenet, do yourself a favor and look anywhere else. Many more cons to list...
Advice to Management
COMMUNICATE with the people on the front lines. Stop caring so much about the bottom line and think of your employees as people and not expenses. Labor is cheaper overseas but you get what you pay for.

pros: Family / Individual healthcare coverage is comparable and competitive with similar companies.
cons:
The PTO policy has changed to a zero hour roll over from year to year. Whereas we used to cap out at 436 hours and could roll over all unused PTO, it is now a use it or lose it benefit which allows for absolutely no cushion of safety for employees who like to keep enough hours saved in case of major illnesses or injury. Generous PTO with a fair cap used to be my favorite part about working for Tenet, but that’s gone now.
In my 20 years with the company I have seen the education benefits decimated, 401k employer match cut in half, employee stock purchase programs take hit after hit, healthcare benefits, while comparable to other companies, is not as good as it used to be, and they even took away the small bonus of a $25 gift card we used to receive around the Holidays. Now they have taken away the PTO rollover and the PTO sell back programs. 
The company only recognizes 5 paid holidays each year, however you must work the holiday in order to receive 8 hours holiday pay, even when working a 12 hour shift. 

At 20 years with the company I am capped out on my pay, and no longer receive raises. Now they are cutting my benefits. It feels like they’re pushing their long term employees away.
Advice to Management
We’re in a national healthcare worker shortage. You should be offering MUCH more to recruit new employees, and at the same time doing everything you can to retain long time employees.
Helpfu
advice_to_mgmt:
We’re in a national healthcare worker shortage. You should be offering MUCH more to recruit new employees, and at the same time doing everything you can to retain long time employees.

cons:
It's my opinion that the corporate team in Dallas is pretty disconnected to the realities of the inside of a hospital. When unpopular decisions are made at the corporate level that affect the operations of the local hospital, its the local folks who are put in the line of fire having to defend those decisions ... and the corporate people are nowhere to be found to provide support. On the contrary, any request for corporate support is seen as "not being able to hold your own" or "not being strong in difficult situations." 

Also, during my time there, high powered & highly compensated executives in Dallas made ludicrous "strategic" decisions that were not at all going to accomplish what they set out to accomplish. review_title: Hostile and petty. Power driven management and HR.
pros: None that I can think of.
cons:
Things have changed since Tenet Healthcare took over. They are simply a cut throat company which cares nothing about their employees or patient care. Management in this hospital is a joke. They will keep telling you flattering words but in the end your head will end up on the stick. Double standard is strong and present in this hospital. Those who care have to kill themselves to get the jobs done while the rest would do the bare minimum or nothing at all. All they have to do is kissing up to their bosses. The culture in this hospital is to shut your mouth. People are rude and nosy and are a bunch of back stabbers and they will abuse you whenever they can. And if you stand up to those abusers, you will be told that you were reacting badly and HR will be reviewing you. Bottom line, you need to shut your mouth and let those abusers enjoy abusing you or they will turn around and play victims and HR will listen to them but not you. Unethical practices from employees will be swept under the rug, and this is across the whole system not just at downtown facility. Ironically, those follow the rules usually won't get the same tolerance level and instead will be pushed to work harder to cover for those don't do their parts. So being unethical actually is more rewarding.

They treat their employees as if they own us outright. These HR people all act like they are royalty and noble. Not a surprised since these people are not originally from Baptist but got sent here by Tenet. Totally different mind set and attitude. Since Tenet took over, almost all our best employees had left, either for better paid jobs somewhere or simply because they hated how they were treated. We all easily got a new job somewhere else quickly, got paid better, treated better and some of us advanced up the ladder faster. And they no longer offer sick days. You will have to use your vacation time if bad luck strikes and you are too sick to work.

For off shift employees, they would be the ones who got the worst. Their work load is double, triple vs day shift. They would be told to come in on their days off and would be scolded if they have a reaction. And they have to stay late in the morning to attend those stupid forum meetings where employees are asked for their donations to united way. I'm all for helping the community but just because the bosses now decide that they will no longer want to get in at 6 to conduct 1 session for off shift employees, now the whole crew will suffer. Speaking about leadership. We want to go home after giving shift reports, not listening about charity. And no, the 6pm session doesn't help either because night shifters come in at 10pm.

Baptist has become a nightmare and Tenet is running it to the ground. Their mentality is they don't need to retain you at all cost because they have that school which produces a bunch of new healthcare workers each year for them. They care nothing about their employees, even cut down on lunch menus. Cost for lunch goes up, options go down. We got like 10 cents for pay raise last year. It's pathetic. To evaluate our performances, they used a list of duties which was generalized by including all the responsibilities from all units. So if you are a nurse and the non nursing departments' performance dropped, you will be punished for it as well. So you kill yourself for a whole year trying to earn a good pay raise and in the end you are punished for someone else's mistakes. And everybody knows the whole hospital is short staffed but we kept hearing about the low productivity. It's easy to sit in your office all day and speculate instead of getting out there and see for yourself. If there are 7-8 patients per nurse, then it's delusional to talk about low productivity.
Advice to Management
Stop lying. We are not kids and we are tired of your lies and empty promises. Start treating employees with respects. And get rid of the double standards. You are not the only hospital in town, stop acting like you are noble.
Helpful (7)
Tenet Healthcare Response
September 14, 2019 – Recruitment & HR Operations
Thank you for leaving an honest review about our management. It is important that our employees feel they can be heard at all times
advice_to_mgmt: Stop lying. We are not kids and we are tired of your lies and empty promises. Start treating employees with respects. And get rid of the double standards. You are not the only hospital in town, stop acting like you are noble.

cons:
mer Engagement in Dallas, TX
Doesn't Recommend
Neutral Outlook
Disapproves of CEO
I worked at Tenet Healthcare full-time for more than a year
Pros
Family atmosphere. Generally fun-loving but very serious when there's work to be done.
Cons
Reshuffling from regional to national marketing structure and a top-down executive change-out left many like me working for people ill-equipped to manage us to our full potential. A common problem not unique to Tenet.
Advice to Management
The costs savings of eliminating the regional layer will never be realized. Micromanaging all the properties from one office is something they are simply not equipped or staffed to do. Adding a high-powered agency helps but they balked at the big-time NY agency advance required to begin work/media buys.

pros:
They pay well, but it is totally not worth the $ for the pain you go through. 
The office is nice.
I really can't think of any other pros.
cons:
This company is going down hill very quickly. There is a good ole boy CEO who seems to be missing the point. A lot of new people have been brought in, but they have no idea what is going on. The higher ups do not talk to anyone below a Sr Director. Unfortunately, the director down level are the ones doing the work. Decisions happen, but tools and platforms are not taken into consideration. So what is being asked means hours of work arounds. When the people in charge of the tools tell them that there is a better way to do it, they do not listen. It's their way or the highway. The phrase worker smarter not harder means nothing to many. You bust your butt 7 days a week to stay ahead while higher ups implement items that make no sense. There is no communication from them on WHY these decisions are made.
Advice to Management
COMMUNICATE to your entire team. Do not trust that a SR Dir is doing it because they are not. If you want your team to support you and Tenet then they need to understand why these decisions are being made. Without the communication, the decisions really make no sense. You have a lot of unhappy people. A year ago, I would have had many positive things to say.
Helpful (6

review_title: Management Needs a Rigorous Time Management Course
pros: Competitive Pay, Good Benefits if you work in the Dallas Office, others will have to fly there for treatment, as there are few plan-approved providers in other states.
cons:
Outrageously abusive company constantly fires groups of staff then makes them re-appy for their jobs. Constantly being asked to "flex." Chronic responsibility without authority -- every task is a "Mother May I" or "Simon Says" to get to the next step, and all the while everyone wanted the task done yesterday.
Advice to Management
Company to hire a third party Conflict Consulting firm where employees, as a last resort before quitting, can get an unbiased management expert involved to mediate inept management and workflow conflicts. All levels of management need to enroll in a rigorous time management course.

pros: Above average salaries for senior level people. More annual holidays than most companies offer these days.
cons:
Horrible downtown location with crappy parking for people who have less than 15 years of experience or who aren't senior leaders. The parking garage is dangerous and my friends have had their cars vandalized. Not safe. Crappy 401k match. Non-existent stock program and options because the senior leaders have mismanaged things so badly that the stock isn't worth jack. Arrogant, self-serving, egotistical, unethical leaders (mostly those closest to the now-departing CEO) who get away with childish, unprofessional, spoiled behavior while the employees suffer for it. No room for advancement unless you are in the small "chosen circle" of people liked by senior leaders. HR leaders brag about owning culture. They should be instead hiding the fact that they are responsible for the most pitiful lack of positive culture. People operate from fear and a desire to backstab to protect themselves. HR will respond to this review saying, "Call so-and-so to further discuss your concerns." The person they list to call is part of the same long-term problem, as are many people in HR.. People are sometimes hired on looks instead of capabilities. There is ageism throughout the company. They just slashed regional management, a market CEO and have laid off people, all because the company was bloated and spending money on the wrong things. Very poor leadership, which is now coming home to roost. Public Affairs leadership is the opposite of what it should be - also arrogant, spoiled, tyrannical, tactical, practices favortism. Wouldn't know good public affairs practice if it hit them in the mouth. Public Affairs leadership should be wiped clean along with the other leaders who are going away soon or have already been terminated. The company is being stripped down to get rid of the debt caused by poor management, and being prepared to be sold to hopefully a better company. I feel sorry for people who work there now. There are good people who will suffer because of what senior leaders have brought about. And yet, departing leaders will have the most ridiculously large severance packages, while other rank and file employees can barely get by - and they're the ones caring for patients each day. Something is fishy with this outcome!
Advice to Management
Your failure to lead, and your arrogance and poor employee treatment, has brought you to where you are now. Maybe you'll learn from this miserable time and be better wherever you land next - that is - if you don't retire from all that insane severance pay you're receiving. Consider treating employees like the mature, intelligent people they are. Stop practicing obvious ageism. All people have value in the company. Not just the young 20-somethings that you find attractive. Learn to trust and let other people lead in areas where they are good. Stop micromanaging because...how has that worked out for you so far? Potential employees - get the heck away from this company and go elsewhere. Do your research online and see how bad this company and its leaders have been. It's just starting - get out now, or don't ever go to Tenet in the first place. There are far better places in DFW with real cultures, real good leaders and real careers. Stay away from Tenet.

review_title: Typical Old-School Corporate Gig: Exhausting, Toxic and Tone Deaf
pros: Higher than average salary; a few good folks in C-suite leadership
cons:
Typical old-school corporate environment. No employee development program. Training and talent program is lackluster and embarrassing, which, in turn, promotes an environment of unapologetic back-stabbing and infighting among employees and leadership. Really, really surreal to watch directors stab VPs stab other VPs and SVPs. I thought management books just made up these scenarios for teaching purposes. Nope! At Tenet it's live action corporate toxicity 24/7. There was even an entire team of VPs and directors, none of whom received merit promotions -- and most employees on the floor knew these "leaders" were promoted only because they threatened to leave. To top if off, Tenet's use of technological solutions is almost non-existent, primarily because the CEO gave away huge contracts to his old college buddies whose companies are shamefully behind the times and overpriced. Pretty incredible to watch a $10 billion healthcare company being effortlessly set up for failure by boys in business suits.
Advice to Management
Too many barriers in leadership to overcome at this point. Sell the company and try again another day.
Helpful (4
advice_to_mgmt: Too many barriers in leadership to overcome at this point. Sell the company and try again another day.

pros: Promises of additional monies for raises and salaries, better administrative structure, additional payors and vendors.
cons:
Redistribution of accountability, communication issues with old vs. new policies.
Advice to Management
When involved with takeovers of facilities, it would be helpful to communicate truthfully any and all expectations (of yours or theirs) with the acquired facility staff in a timely fashion. Rather than set high hopes, only to turn around and sell portions of the facility behind closed doors to other hospital groups for any reason, transparency is a must. Instead, those of us left manning the ship have imaginary titles given to us in lieu of appropriate pay with little hope of resolution to any issues that arise as a result of transitions or as a matter of course.

pros: None, Tenet is the poster child for everything and anything that is wrong with for profit healthcare. Mode of operation is to buy up distressed hospitals and cut spending on staff and equipment to boost profitability. While some local leadership is somewhat competent overall this "top down" organization is driven by profit to the detriment of care and safety.
cons:
Some of the arthroscopic and surgical equipment was 3 generations outdated, with poor optical resolution and marginally functioning instrumentation. Imaging was still retained in analog VCR format. Some data systems are DOS based relics, with a elevated risk of data loss and integrity compromise. Unable to retain highly qualified clinical and administrative staff, in the four hospitals I worked with.
Advice to Management
Listen to your physians (if you can keep them) and clinical staff. Scrap your "drive by" Lean Improvement Initiative that disrupts meaningful locally driven improvement in Safety, Quality and Delivery of care in order to maximize profit margin. The Dallas needs many more clinicians with a strong voice in leadership and a lot fewer Finance wonks running the business.

The work environment is unhealthy, both physically and mentally.

stent employment during the winter/respiratory seasons. Reasonable benefits for full-timers except 401K.

Directors don't last and its a constant back and forth. Expect to be flexed ALOT during the summer months. COOs only care about money and don't care about staff or patient care.

review_title: For Profit Healthcare focused on $ not Patient care
pros: Large organization with locations around the country. Offer the latest technology to draw great employed doctors. Benefits and pay is very competitive.
cons:
As managers, Tenet has blurred lines in its organizational charts to help understand who is truly the decision maker (administration or high priced employed physician) - these "blurred lines" remove the focus on its patients from thier mission and purpose in the community 
Individual Hospitals work in silos from each other in regional markets, many local hospitals fight for the same market share by providing same high dollar specialtis rather than pooling this strengths and reducing costs
Advice to Management
Tenet is known for advancing it's own management into executive positions, especially if ones are from Tenet Leadership Academy, which is great. But, if Tenet wants to break the cycle of barely hitting the shareholder's expectations, you should allow more outside hires to help challenge the culture and chanel Tenet's Reputation.

pros: Excellence in employed physicians. They have fortunately hired some of the best in Florida. This kept me motivated in continuing to manage over 30 physician practices in 8 years.
cons:
Poor administrative decisions. Nothing is as important as "making budget" and moving friends up the corporate latter. Decisions are not based on what is best for the organization or its employees. Managers are never recognized or appreciated for all that they do, yet are held accountable for bottom lines, though they have little under their control. It is expected that they have no personal and work life balance. Hard work, loyalty and dedication are overlooked. HR provides no support. Turn over is extremely high in the physician practice setting, from support staff, office managers, practice administrators, directors, HR, finance (in actuality in every position). Positions have been eliminated but the same role and expectations exist for a lower paying title.
Advice to Management
Support you managers. Pay them their worth. Show appreciation for all they have done for the organization. Maybe then you can retain employees whose work ethics represent the valued physicians you employ.
Helpful (1
advice_to_mgmt: Support you managers. Pay them their worth. Show appreciation for all they have done for the organization. Maybe then you can retain employees whose work ethics represent the valued physicians you employ.

pros: Satisfied with current pay rate and PTO accrual rate. Easy going atmosphere most of the time.
cons:

Namely, any member of the physical rehabilitation department - physical, occupational and speech therapists who all have advanced degrees. The hospital I work at has been part of Tenet for approximately 2 yrs and they did not provide the reimbursement before becoming Tenet. It is difficult to know if other tenet hospitals actually do provide this benefit, but we have been told we are not going to receive this benefit in the distant future.

review_title: Dallas Home Office Marketing Dept. Is The Best
pros:
The marketing department leadership is very focused on minimizing politics, maximizing collaboration, encouraging transparency and fostering innovation. The department is full of smart, experienced, friendly, and very dedicated teammates who naturally work hard together to achieve goals. I'm respected as a person and given the benefit of the doubt, so I feel comfortable stepping up to try to add value where I can. I love my teammates and feeling like I'm making a difference. 

The Tenet perks are also great. I keep learning about more of them on a regular basis. And the newly remodeled floors are very bright and beautiful, with great views. It's a great place to go to work every day.
cons:
This is not the place for someone who wants to skate by doing the minimum, or create cliques. Even extremely talented and experienced leaders are rolling up their sleeves to dig in to accomplish our ambitious goals. 

The location is beautiful but downtown itself is a little inconvenient (although right on 75, 35 and the Tollway) especially for so many of us who have kids in schools up north. However, you can have flexible hours when needed and they provide perks at the location like a free shuttle to anywhere downtown, free parking of course, and a new conference center to bring in caterers for lunchtime. I heard they will also have a doctor on site (like a small urgent care clinic). You can also get to cafes and food courts through the building.
Advice to Management
Recognize The Bus Dev/Marketing leadership for creating the collaborative and productive team environment we all love. More teams should be run like this. Great job!!
Helpful (1
advice_to_mgmt: Recognize The Bus Dev/Marketing leadership for creating the collaborative and productive team environment we all love. More teams should be run like this. Great job!!

review_title: Profits over Patients 100% of the time
pros: Unionized Hospital and pay is very good for Registered NurseStaff. The hospital that I work at is a busy trauma center so its good learning environment the work is varied and interesting. Recently invested in a lift team due to California Law not because they wanted to.
cons:
You work in terrible conditions for the pay. The exceptions are set way too high and given the scarcity of resources. Limited supplies, old equipment that doesn't function properly. On a daily basis including taking care of critically ill and unstable patients you have do all menial clerical tasks, no nursing assistants, no Physical Therapy. The hospital is also very dirty. This includes but is not limited to answering telephones, printing progress notes, answering the door, counseling family members, and generally the lack of resources leads to an unsafe working environment for the staff and patients. I have been in nursing 5 years and I received my first injury at this hospital and have been assaulted by patients on numerous occasions with management discouraging its reporting or seeking treatment.
Advice to Management
Focus on providing patient centered care first. The focus on lean management and profits is over the top and not good for our patients, their families, community, and employees. The results of this type of Profit centered healthcare are evident. Patient falls, central line infections, and a staggering amount of bed sores. I wouldn't take a love one here or receive treatment here myself it is frightening the care that is given at this health facility why do you think the State of California is here constantly investigating the care. Stop trying to squeeze every penny and get away with being barely legal and get up to standards and just do what is right for our patients.

pros: its come a LONG time way since I started working here many years ago but has a ways to go still. Recently we were fortunate enough to finally have a very decent amount of funding for our hospital to updat so many pieces of antiquated equipment and monitoring systems in almost every department. So very necessary in light of the many changes in healthcare today.
cons:
Compensation is low for this area. Huge deal made about discussing salary with anyone else (dismissable offense) not really sure that's legal! Under new leadership very recently, hoping this will somehow change attitudes. Hospital really doesn't follow its own rules, (Policy and procedures) except when the JCAHO inspections come up then everyone tries to remember the correct rules not the ones that were being followed since last inspection.
Advice to Management
If you leave employment with Tenet Health work somewhere else for a bit and then negotiate your return you could end up making more than your manager! If you stay employed with Tenet for a long time your increases are smaller than cost of living rise. New graduates can come in at barely just lower than you are paid having been there for a decade or longer. Really can't understand why management can't see this. What is the incentive to really want to work to your best capacity?
Leadership? It's just not there. People get promoted, not because they deserve it but because they have been there the next longest and therefore get it. They are not trained for the respective managerial, lead nurse, head tech job but have to figure it out. Many don't stay long. What's the point?

pros: You get to work with some wonderful, talented and very hard-working colleagues. In addition, salaries at Tenet tend to be very competitive for both the market, industry and skill level. They do reward their employees financially - and for that I am grateful. I also believe that, overall, from a financial standpoint, Tenet is a very well-run company. I also believe that Trevor Fetter, the CEO, is incredibly smart and is probably one of the most skilled CEOs I've ever seen. That deserves to be said.
cons:
Many departments at headquarters (which Tenet calls "the Home Office") are poorly managed. Leaders can be incredibly difficult to work with, changing their minds at whim and expecting you to work sometimes ridiculous hours (and often do the job of more then one person - literally!). There's no such thing as work-life balance for many leaders at Tenet. Instead, they refer to "work-life integration." Finally, at headquarters, every single employee is forced to work in a cubicle - including the CEO. It's horrific. There is absolutely ZERO privacy, and it's often so loud it's virtually impossible to get any serious or significant work done. employee_status: IT Business Analyst in Dallas, TX

They pay well.

I don't have much else

I feel like everyone on my floor only shows up for the paycheck. That's no judgement, I just need a purpose beyond $ to get up in the AM. We never talk about patients or the impact what we do has on them. 

The place is so big and so many people are confused it takes months to learn where to go for anything. Half the company support is outsourced to Dell and no one ever seems to know who does what. I sit by 20 people and maybe 2 are actual Tenet employees. The rest are contractors from various companies. It makes the culture bland, $ centered and depressing. No one has any fun at work because everyone works as if a 2 minutes break will get them fired. 

They pay well...because their health insurance is expensive. I've never worked for a healthcare company with worse insurance. Feeling like I can't protect my loved ones is a cause of great stress. 

They don't offer tuition reimbursement which makes me feel like they aren't interested in employee personal growth, but that could be me.

401K match is 50% up to first 6% but it requires that you be with the company 1000 hours before you qualify.. Basically if you get hired at the wrong time it might be two years before you're eligible for a match.
Advice to Management
Work harder to develop a patient centered culture

pros: They offer a full benefits package - health, dental, vision, 401K. They don't expect any nights or weekend hours, overtime is limited.
cons:
Tenet knows how to run hospitals, but has been running the physician practices by trial and error. The success of the acquisition really comes down to the physicians and the manager since the corporate structure does not set up the practice for success.
Advice to Management
Pick one initiative at a time. Focus on one or two areas of improvement and wait for things to improve before piling on more. It's a lot harder to do twenty things well versus two. Have consistent training so that the different offices still have some commonalities but understand that different speciality offices require different workflow.

review_title: Demanding, but believe that my hard work is making a difference
pros: Paid Time Off has never been an issue for me. I have 25 days a year and can generally use them when I want. In addition I get 11 or more paid holidays off and perhaps one of the best perks is that the corporate office is closed during the week between Christmas and New Year's. My work-life balance has changed somewhat since the Vanguard Health Systems acquisition in the fall of 2013.
cons:
I still have a lot of flexibility in terms of work hours and telecommuting. Sometimes it feels like I work in more of a matrix organizational structure, which means getting pulled in several competing directions. This provides exposure to different areas of the business (=PRO), but can mean that managing projects and expectations can be difficult (=CON). There also tends to be a lack of communication and positive feedback. This tends to mean that decisions by management and steering committees often do not happen or when they do, they tend to result in rework.
Advice to Management
Make sure to clearly communicate goals and expectations. Provide positive feedback to inspire your employees. And lastly, retain talent by talking to them and learning about their strengths and what makes them passionate about what they do. It's amazing what listening and a little feedback can do to energize your staff.
Helpful (4
advice_to_mgmt: Make sure to clearly communicate goals and expectations. Provide positive feedback to inspire your employees. And lastly, retain talent by talking to them and learning about their strengths and what makes them passionate about what they do. It's amazing what listening and a little feedback can do to energize your staff.

pros: Tenet is a capable organization with many strong individuals in key positions. cons:
Suffers from traditional large company issues. Multiple overlapping departments that work in silos with the this is someone else's job mentality.
Advice to Management
Reorganize to align with operational requirements rather than functional needs to interject operational knowledge into process. Reduce resourcing redundancy and increase individual responsibility levels within the organization to promote ownership and improved results.

The majority of the nurses I work with wish they could work someplace else. Now what does 
that tell you ? I wish I could say it was better, I truely do, but working conditions seem to be going from bad to worse. It's skeleton staffing all the way, working 12 hour shifts with no lunch and staying over to chart . From the begining of their acquisition of the hospital the management has instituted and adversarial , domineering mode of operation. Stringent in requirements and control and unforgivingly severe in discipline
Advice to Management
Try treating your employees like human beings. Be fair and honest. Make them feel valued and not like you are trying to find ways to fire them. Increase you nurse to patient ratios to meet other hospitals in the area. Remember that kindness trickles down

pros: Great co-workers at the facility level. A-Team seems to try their best despite a clueless home office. Front line staff is awesome.
cons:
While individual facilities are run by great people, the corporate entity is as bad as they come. They are completely out of touch and create an environment of fear to gain profitability. The corporate office puts shareholders ahead of all else. Anyone, in any position, could be fired in order to hit budget. Patient care is often compromised due to lack of resources and run down facilities. I can't even begin to comprehend the reasoning behind some of their decisions. Either they encourage turnover to keep costs down, or are truly incompetent- either of which is unacceptable. 

Benefits are beyond terrible. Wages are below market standards in every department. There is no loyalty towards employees from home office. 

Tenet is a place to work, while you search for something better- Nothing more.
Advice to Management
Individual management is doing a great job. Home office is hopeless. On an individual note, I do not normally advocate for unionization, but would fully encourage it at my facility. It is probably the only means for employees to give themselves a fair shake in our market.

pros:
1) The Senior Leadership (Fetter, Porter) are brilliant professionals. They have done a very good job turning the company in the right direction over the recent years after a very difficult time for the company. They also are very inspiring leaders who address the entire company regularly.
2) The IA department travels to all the hospitals. Some of those hospitals aren't in high crime areas.
3) Outside of the IA department, there are some very intelligent, dedicated, and talented individuals who have been with the company for many years.
4) Initial compensation is fair. Benefits are also good.
cons:
1) The size of the company can make bureaucracy a problem. Each region has a very tall reporting structure, so implementing solutions can be a challenge if there is even one mid-level director who opposes a directive set by senior management.
2) Management in the IA department is at best, ineffective or aloof; at worst, toxic and spiteful.
3) While the IA department does travel, the work in the field is extreme in terms of hours per day. Burnout is common and largely ignored as management typically only participates in one or two half-days of work at the hospitals, mostly intended to serve a "police" function.
Advice to Management
The Company has made tremendous strides since the missteps in the early 2000's. There are a lot of good programs being implemented at the hospital level. However, the IA department, because of the issues listed above, tends to underachieve because so much energy is directed at office politics and infighting and away from professional growth and actual audit work.

review_title: Tenet Healthcares REAL Performance & Improvement Plan
pros:
Tenet Healthcare is a fairly good corporate employer for the following reasons:
1. Healthcare is a necessity of life, and jobs are almost always available; excesive cut backs have not been a concern for this corporation.
2. The benefits, while downzied during economic turmoil, are still competitive. These include health insurance, 401K, tuition reimbursement, accidental/life insurance.
3. Managment tends to relate to employees personal needs (i.e. child care, sick time, personal days), and seem to make accomodations for a work / life balance. 
4. The company values those who seek further education and seem to promote a learning environment. 
5. Because of the incentives for learning and personal growth, Tenet seems to find room for employees to grow and move up after completion of degree programs or certifications.
cons:
Some of the downsides of working for Tenet Healthcare include the following:
1. As seen in many corporations, Tenet has some administrators or managers that have been around for too long. Sadly, these people add nothing more to the departments than nostalgia of times past. In an effort to maintain competiveness in any given industry, a corporation must be willing to identify problems and implement effective policies and procedures to correct the problem. As such, employees may find recurrent "fires" or problems in departments that cannot be put out. This can cause frustration among the staff.
2. While education is valued and reimbursed by Tenet, do not expect management to advise you of newly opened positions. They will not show an employee the way out if it does not suit their interests.
Advice to Management
In light of the afore mentioned issues, I would suggest the following to the administrators of Tenet Healthcare:
1. Remove or reassign ineffective administrators or managers. Information can be obtained by improving or expanding upon the questions given in the annual employee satisfaction survey, or by hiring a consulting firm. I would highly recommend the latter, as internal sources may be biased, providing unreliable or inaccurate data.
2. Create a bulliten board designed especially for those who are seeking further education. Post notes and letters on this board (which can be either physical or web-based) informing employees of new positions or helpful hints that can lead them to success within the organization.
Helpful (4
advice_to_mgmt:
In light of the afore mentioned issues, I would suggest the following to the administrators of Tenet Healthcare:
1. Remove or reassign ineffective administrators or managers. Information can be obtained by improving or expanding upon the questions given in the annual employee satisfaction survey, or by hiring a consulting firm. I would highly recommend the latter, as internal sources may be biased, providing unreliable or inaccurate data.

review_title: One of the best jobs I've EVER had!
pros: Excellent work environment. Hospital and managers support continuing education and growth. Managers treat employees with respect and as equals. Unlike most hospitals, this one doesn't work it's employees to death! Insurance and benefits are reasonably priced and overall pretty good especially for prenatal services.
cons:
The patient volume isn't always really high so sometimes we have to "flex" which means we may not work a day or we may only work a half day. For me personally, the salary is high enough that I don't really have to worry too much about it but when there are 2-3 days in a week that I'm leaving after only 3-4 hours it does sometimes make me a little nervous but so far, it has not impacted me in a negative way. Also, the insurance has a deductible which I'm not used to and don't particularly like so I use my spouse's as a secondary. The PTO could be better, its only about 4.93 hours every 2 weeks.
Advice to Management
Keep doing what you are doing! Your employees (at least at my location) are very happy!

review_title: First and last time I will work for for-profit company
pros: My immediate supervisor is great and they pay me well
cons:
The care is pt centered only in re: to litigation and profits. There are no extras here. No frills for pts, MDs, or employees.
Advice to Management
The "A-Team" (this is really the name they have given themselves) need to come out of their offices into the heart of the hospital- the clinical areas. Try walking a mile in those shoes.

review_title: Too focused on financials, not enough on patient care.
pros: Good compensation and benefits, young, energetic management and directors.
cons:
So unstable, multiple layoffs every year, extremely high admin and management turnover, avoid working here if you don't want to be back in the job market in a few months.
Advice to Management
Fix corporate to hospital communication and resources, figure out how to run a practice management side of the business, quit laying off your best people.

review_title: Never know if you'll have a job from day to day.
pros: Good pay and benefits after years on the job.
cons:
I was laid off from Tenet/Conifer after 10 years on the job along with about 300 others because they are sending jobs over seas. The management treated us as bad as possible, within the law, to try to get us to quit so they would not have to pay unemployment or severence. Supervisors are uneducated and unprofessional. Ethics policy is a joke.
Advice to Management
It's all about the money, Tenet/Conifer would be a good company if management cared as much about the employees and customers as they do the dollar.
Helpfu

cons:
Many things, in my opinion. Pay rate, paid time off, processes, communications, employee morale just to name a few things.
Advice to Management

pros: Never learned so much in a company, you are a part of many different projects where your opinion and knowledge is respected.
cons:
Since the organization is private, they continually have lay-offs, due to restructuring and outsourcing to overseas. I was one of 200+ individuals who lost their jobs in 2011. The decisions were not based on how good of a job we were all doing, more so senority, which some may take comfort in, but when you're kiling yourself for the organization, you'd think there would be some loyalty in return.
Advice to Management
American companies should employ people living in America...stop outsourcing...it's a bad reflection on the organizations loyalty to the country that is making them as successful as they are!
